qas.question: According to Vaisesika philosophy, how many substances comprise reality?
What are the substances of Vaisesika reality?
Of what does Vaisesika philosophy say the things are made ?
According to Vaisesika what is divisible into atoms?
What form are atoms in Vaisesika?
What does Vaisesika teach is able to be destroyed?
What is not a function of atoms?
What is the name of a substance's special dimension?

context: Vaiśeṣika metaphysical premises are founded on a form of atomism, that the reality is composed of <a0_0><b5_0>four<b5_0/><a0_0/> substances (<a1_0>earth, water, air, fire<a1_0/>). Each of these four are of two types: atomic (paramāṇu) and <b9_0>composite<b9_0/>. <b6_0>An atom<b6_0/> is, according to Vaiśeṣika scholars, that which is indestructible (anitya), indivisible, and has a special kind of dimension, called “small” (<b8_0>aṇu<b8_0/>). A <a3_0>composite<a3_0/>, in this philosophy, is defined to be anything which is divisible into <a2_0>atoms<a2_0/>. <b7_0>Whatever human beings perceive<b7_0/> is composite, while atoms are <a4_0>invisible<a4_0/>. The Vaiśeṣikas stated that size, form, truths and everything that human beings experience as a whole is a function of atoms, their number and their spatial arrangements, their guṇa (quality), karma (activity), sāmānya (commonness), viśeṣa (particularity) and amavāya (inherence, inseparable connectedness of everything).
